verses.text: The Author's Design.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:53
verses.text: That the composition of a history of the Church was Eusebius' own idea, and was not due to any suggestion from without, seems clear, both from the absence of reference to any one else as prompting it, and from the lack of a dedication at the beginning of the work.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:54
verses.text: The reasons which led him to undertake its composition seem to have been both scientific and apologetic.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:55
verses.text: He lived, and he must have realized the fact, at the opening of a new age in the history of the Church.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:56
verses.text: He believed, as he frequently tells us, that the period of struggle had come to an end, and that the Church was now about entering upon a new era of prosperity.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:57
verses.text: He must have seen that it was a peculiarly fitting time to put on record for the benefit of posterity the great events which had taken place within the Church during the generations that were past, to sum up in one narrative all the trials and triumphs which had now emerged in this final and greatest triumph, which he was witnessing.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:58
verses.text: He wrote, as any historian of the present day would write, for the information and instruction of his contemporaries and of those who should come after, and yet there was in his mind all the time the apologetic purpose, the desire to exhibit to the world the history of Christianity as a proof of its divine origin and efficacy.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:59
verses.text: The plan which he proposed to himself is stated at the very beginning of his work: "It is my purpose to write an account of the successions of the holy apostles, as well as of the times which have elapsed from the days of our Saviour to our own; and to relate how many and how important events are said to have occurred in the history of the Church; and to mention those who have governed and presided over the Church in the most prominent parishes, and those who in each generation have proclaimed the divine word either orally or in writing.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:60
verses.text: It is my purpose also to give the names and the number and the times of those who through love of innovation have run into the greatest errors, and proclaiming themselves discoverers of knowledge, falsely so-called, have, like fierce wolves, unmercifully devastated the flock of Christ.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:61
verses.text: It is my intention, moreover, to recount the misfortunes which immediately came upon the whole Jewish nation in consequence of their plots against our Saviour, and to record the ways and the times in which the divine word has been attacked by the Gentiles, and to describe the character of those who at various periods have contended for it in the face of blood and tortures, as well as the confessions which have been made in our own days, and finally the gracious and kindly succour which our Saviour afforded them all".

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:62
verses.text: It will be seen that Eusebius had a very comprehensive idea of what a history of the Church should comprise, and that he was fully alive to its importance.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:64
verses.text: Eusebius as a Historian.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:65
verses.text: The Merits and Defects of his History.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:66
verses.text: The whole Christian world has reason to be thankful that there lived at the opening of the fourth century a man who, with his life spanning one of the greatest epochs that has occurred in the history of the Church, with an intimate experimental knowledge of the old and of the new condition of things, was able to conceive so grand a plan and possessed the means and the ability to carry it out.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:67
verses.text: Had he written nothing else, Eusebius' Church History would have made him immortal; for if immortality be a fitting reward for large and lasting services, few possess a clearer title to it than the author of that work.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:68
verses.text: The value of the History to us lies not in its literary merit, but in the wealth of the materials which it furnishes for a knowledge of the early Church.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:69
verses.text: How many prominent figures of the first three centuries are known to us only from the pages of Eusebius; how many fragments, priceless on account of the light which they shed upon movements of momentous and far-reaching consequence, have been preserved by him alone; how often a hint dropped, a casual statement made in passing, or the mention of some apparently trifling event, gives the clue which enables us to unravel some perplexing labyrinth, or to fit into one whole various disconnected and apparently unrelated elements, and thus to trace the steps in the development of some important historical movement whose rise and whose bearing must otherwise remain an unsolved riddle.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:70
verses.text: The work reveals no sympathy with Ebionism, Gnosticism, and Montanism, and little appreciation of their real nature, and yet our knowledge of their true significance and of their place in history is due in considerable part to facts respecting the movements or their leaders which Eusebius alone has recorded or preserved.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:71
verses.text: To understand the development of the Logos Christology we must comprehend the significance of the teaching of Paul of Samosata, and how inadequate would our knowledge of the nature of that teaching be without the epistle quoted in Book VII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:72
verses.text: chap.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:73
verses.text: How momentous were the consequences of the paschal controversies, and how dark would they be were it not for the light shed upon them by our author.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:74
verses.text: How important, in spite of their tantalizing brevity and obscurity, the fragments of Papias' writings; how interesting the extracts from the memoirs of Hegesippus; how suggestive the meager notices from Dionysius of Corinth, from Victor of Rome, from Melito, from Caius; how instructive the long and numerous quotations from the epistles of Dionysius of Alexandria! He may often fail to appreciate the significance of the events which he records, he may in many cases draw unwarranted conclusions from the premises which he states, he may sometimes misinterpret his documents and misunderstand men and movements, but in the majority of cases he presents us with the material upon which to form our own judgments, and if we differ with him we must at the same time thank him for the data which have enabled us independently to reach other results.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:75
verses.text: But the value of Eusebius' Church History does not lie solely in the fact that it contains so many original sources which would be otherwise unknown to us.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:76
verses.text: It is not merely a thesaurus, it is a history in the truest sense, and it possesses an intrinsic value of its own, independent of its quotations from other works.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:77
verses.text: Eusebius possessed extensive sources of knowledge no longer accessible to us.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:78
verses.text: His History contains the results of his extended perusal of many works which are now irrecoverably lost, of his wide acquaintance with the current traditions of his day, of his familiar intercourse with many of the chief men of the age.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:79
verses.text: If we cut out all the documents which he quotes, there still remains an extensive history whose loss would leave an irreparable blank in our knowledge of the early Church.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:80
verses.text: How invaluable, for instance, to mention but one matter, are the researches of our author in regard to the circulation of the books of the New Testament: his testimony to the condition of the canon in his own time, and to the more or less widespread use of particular writings by the Fathers of preceding centuries.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:81
verses.text: Great as is the value of the sources which Eusebius quotes, those that he does not give are still more extensive, and it is the knowledge gained from them which he has transmitted to us.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:82
verses.text: The worth of these portions of his History must depend in the first place upon the extent and reliability of his sources, and in the second place upon the use which he made of them.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:83
verses.text: A glance at the list of his authorities given in the index, reveals at once the immense range of his materials.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:84
verses.text: The number of books which he either quotes or refers to as read is enormous.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:85
verses.text: When to these are added the works employed by him in the composition of his Praep.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:88
verses.text: He must have been a voracious reader from his earliest years, and he must have possessed extraordinary acquisitive powers.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:89
verses.text: It is safe to say that there was among the Fathers, with the possible exception of Origen, no more learned man than he.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:90
verses.text: He thus possessed one of the primary qualifications of the historian.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:91
verses.text: And yet even in this respect he had his limitations.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:92
verses.text: He seems to have taken no pains to acquaint himself with the works of heretics, but to have been content to take his knowledge of them at second hand.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:93
verses.text: And still further, he was sadly ignorant of Latin literature and of the Latin Church in general (see below, p.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:94
verses.text: ); in fact, we must not expect to glean from his History a very thorough or extended knowledge of western Christendom.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:95
verses.text: But his sources were not confined to literary productions.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:96
verses.text: He had a wide acquaintance with the world, and he was enabled to pick up much from his intercourse with other men and with different peoples that he could not have found upon the shelves of the Caesarean or of any other library.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:97
verses.text: Moreover, he had access to the archives of state and gathered from them much information quite inaccessible to most men.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:98
verses.text: He was thus peculiarly fitted, both by nature and by circumstances, for the task of acquiring material, the first task of the genuine historian.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:99
verses.text: But the value of his work must depend in the second place upon the wisdom and honesty with which he used his sources, and upon the faithfulness and accuracy with which he reproduced the results thus reached.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:100
verses.text: We are therefore led to enquire as to his qualifications for this part of his work.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:101
verses.text: We notice, in the first place, that he was very diligent in the use of his sources.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:102
verses.text: Nothing seems to have escaped him that might in any way bear upon the particular subject in hand.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:103
verses.text: When he informs us that a certain author nowhere mentions a book or an event, he is, so far as I am aware, never mistaken.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:104
verses.text: When we realize how many works he read entirely through for the sake of securing a single historical notice, and how many more he must have read without finding anything to his purpose, we are impressed with his untiring diligence.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:105
verses.text: To-day, with our convenient indexes, and with the references at hand which have been made by many other men who have studied the writings of the ancients, we hardly comprehend what an amount of labor the production of a History like Eusebius' must have cost him, a pioneer in that kind of work.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:106
verses.text: In the second place, we are compelled to admire the sagacity which our author displays in the selection of his materials.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:107
verses.text: He possessed the true instinct of the historian, which enabled him to pick out the salient points and to present to the reader just that information which he most desires.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:108
verses.text: We shall be surprised upon examining his work to see how little it contains which it is not of the utmost importance for the student of early Church history to know, and how shrewdly the author has anticipated most of the questions which such a student must ask.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:109
verses.text: He saw what it was in the history of the first three centuries of the Church which posterity would most desire to know, and he told them.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:110
verses.text: His wisdom in this respect is all the more remarkable when compared with the unwisdom of most of his successors, who filled their works with legends of saints and martyrs, which, however fascinating they may have been to the readers of that age, possess little either of interest or of value for us.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:111
verses.text: When he wishes to give us a glimpse of the persecutions of those early days, his historical and literary instinct leads him to dwell especially upon two thoroughly representative cases,—the martyrdom of Polycarp and the sufferings of the churches of Lyons and Vienne,—and to preserve for posterity two of the noblest specimens of martyrological literature which the ancient Church produced.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:112
verses.text: It is true that he sometimes erred in his judgment as to the wants of future readers; we could wish that he had been somewhat fuller and clearer on many points, and that he had not so entirely neglected some others; but on the whole I am of the opinion that few historical works, ancient or modern, have in the same compass better fulfilled their mission in this respect.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:113
verses.text: In the third place, we can hardly fail to be impressed by the wisdom with which Eusebius discriminated between reliable and unreliable sources.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:114
verses.text: Judged by the modern standard he may fall short as a literary critic, but judged by the standard of antiquity he must be given a very high rank.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:115
verses.text: Few indeed are the historians of ancient times, secular or ecclesiastical, who can compare with Eusebius for sound judgment in this matter.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:116
verses.text: The general freedom of his work from the fables and prodigies, and other improbable or impossible tales which disfigure the pages of the great majority even of the soberest of ancient historians, is one of its most marked features.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:117
verses.text: He shows himself uncommonly particular in demanding good evidence for the circumstances which he records, and uncommonly shrewd in detecting spurious and unreliable sources.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:118
verses.text: When we remember the great number of pseudonymous works which were current in his day we are compelled to admire his care and his discrimination.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:119
verses.text: Not that he always succeeded in detecting the false.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:120
verses.text: More than once he was sadly at fault (as for instance in regard to the Abgarus correspondence and Josephus' testimony to Christ), and has in consequence been severely denounced or held up to unsparing ridicule by many modern writers.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:121
verses.text: But the wonder certainly is not that he erred as often as he did, but that he did not err oftener; not that he was sometimes careless in regard to the reliability of his sources, but that he was ever as careful as, in the majority of cases, he has proved himself to be.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:122
verses.text: In fact, comparing him with other writers of antiquity, we cannot commend too highly the care and the skill with which he usually discriminated between the true and the false.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:123
verses.text: In the fourth place, he deserves all praise for his constant sincerity and unfailing honesty.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:124
verses.text: I believe that emphasis should be laid upon this point for the reason that Eusebius' reputation has often suffered sadly in consequence of the unjust imputations, and the violent accusations, which it was for a long time the fashion to make against him, and which lead many still to treat his statements with distrust, and his character with contempt.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:125
verses.text: Gibbon's estimate of his honesty is well known and has been unquestioningly accepted in many quarters, but it is none the less unjust, and in its implications quite untrue to the facts.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:126
verses.text: Eusebius does dwell with greater fullness upon the virtues than upon the vices of the early Church, upon its glory than upon its shame, and he tells us directly that it is his intention so to do (H.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:129
verses.text: ), but he never undertakes to conceal the sins of the Christians, and the chapter immediately preceding contains a denunciation of their corruptness and wickedness uttered in no faint terms.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:130
verses.text: In fact, in the face of these and other candid passages in his work, it is the sheerest injustice to charge him with dishonesty and unfairness because he prefers, as almost any Christian historian must, to dwell with greater fullness of detail upon the bright than upon the dark side of the picture.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:131
verses.text: Scientific, Eusebius' method, in this respect, doubtless is not; but dishonest, no one has a right to call it.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:132
verses.text: The most severe attack which has been made upon Eusebius in recent years is found in an article by Jachmann (see below, p.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:134
verses.text: The evident animus which runs through his entire paper is very unpleasant; the conclusions which he draws are, to say the least, strained.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:135
verses.text: I cannot enter here into a consideration of his positions; most of them are examined below in the notes upon the various passages which he discusses.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:136
verses.text: The whole article, like most similar attacks, proceeds upon the supposition that our author is guilty, and then undertakes simply to find evidence of that which is already presupposed.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:137
verses.text: I submit that few writers could endure such an ordeal.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:138
verses.text: If Eusebius is tried according to the principles of common justice, and of sound literary criticism, I am convinced, after long and careful study, that his sincerity and honesty of purpose cannot be impeached.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:139
verses.text: The particular instances which have been urged as proving his dishonesty will be discussed below in the notes upon the respective passages, and to those the reader is referred (compare especially pp.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:141
verses.text: Eusebius' critics are wont to condemn him severely for what they are pleased to call the dishonesty displayed by him in his Vita Constantini.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:142
verses.text: Such critics forget, apparently, that that work pretends to be, not a history, but a panegyric.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:143
verses.text: Judging it as such, I am unable to find anything in it which leads me to entertain for a moment a suspicion of the author's honesty.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:144
verses.text: It is true that Eusebius emphasizes the Emperor's good qualities, and fails to mention the darker spots in his character; but so far as I am aware he misstates no facts, and does only what those who eulogize deceased friends are accustomed to do the world over.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:160

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:161

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:173
verses.text: On the other hand, Eusebius as an historian had many very grave faults which it is not my wish in the least to palliate or conceal.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:174
verses.text: One of the most noticeable of these is his complete lack of any conception of historiography as a fine art.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:175
verses.text: His work is interesting and instructive because of the facts which it records, but that interest is seldom if ever enhanced by his mode of presentation.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:176
verses.text: There is little effective grouping, almost no sense of perspective, utter ignorance of the art of suggesting by a single line or phrase a finished picture of a man or of a movement.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:177
verses.text: He was not, in other words, a Thucydides or a Tacitus; but the world has seen not many such as they.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:178
verses.text: A second and still more serious fault is our author's want of depth, if I may so express myself, his failure to look beneath the surface and to grasp the real significance of things, to trace the influence of opinions and events.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:179
verses.text: We feel this defect upon every page.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:180
verses.text: We read the annals, but we are conscious of no masterful mind behind them, digesting and comprehending them into one organic and imposing whole.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:181
verses.text: This radical weakness in our author's method is revealed perhaps most clearly in his superficial and transcendental treatment of heretics and heresies, his failure to appreciate their origin and their bearing upon the progress of Christian thought.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:182
verses.text: Of a development in theology, in fact, he knows nothing, and hence his work lacks utterly that which we now look upon as the most instructive part of Church history,—the history of doctrine.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:183
verses.text: In the third place, severe censure must be passed upon our author for his carelessness and inaccuracy in matters of chronology.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:184
verses.text: We should expect that one who had produced the most extensive chronological work that had ever been given to the world, would be thoroughly at home in that province, but in truth his chronology is the most defective feature of his work.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:185
verses.text: The difficulty is chiefly due to his inexcusable carelessness, we might almost say slovenliness, in the use of different and often contradictory sources of information.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:186
verses.text: Instead of applying himself to the discrepancies, and endeavoring to reach the truth by carefully weighing the respective merits of the sources, or by testing their conclusions in so far as tests are possible, he adopts in many cases the results of both, apparently quite unsuspicious of the confusion consequent upon such a course.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:187
verses.text: In fact, the critical spirit which actuates him in dealing with many other matters seems to leave him entirely when he is concerned with chronology; and instead of proceeding with the care and circumspection of an historian, he accepts what he finds with the unquestioning faith of a child.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:188
verses.text: There is no case in which he can be convicted of disingenuousness, but at times his obtuseness is almost beyond belief.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:189
verses.text: An identity of names, or a resemblance between events recorded by different authors, will often be enough to lead him all unconsciously to himself into the most absurd and contradictory conclusions.

verses.text: This unfortunate habit of Eusebius' is one into which men of wide learning are very apt to fall.

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:205

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:209

verses.name: Eusebius: Church History 1:210
